captions.text: Yes?
Lady Catherine.

The rest of your offspring,
l presume.

All but one, the youngest
has been lately married,
Your Ladyship.

And my eldest was proposed to,
only this afternoon.

You have a very
small garden, madam.

Could l offer you
a cup of tea, perhaps, Your--

Absolutely not.
l need to speak to
Miss Elizabeth Bennet alone.
As a matter of urgency.

You can be of no loss,
Miss Bennet, to understand
why l am here.

lndeed you're mistaken.
l cannot account
for this honor at all.

Miss Bennet, l warn you,
l am not to be trifled with.

A report of a most alarming
nature has reached me...

that you intend to be united
with my nephew, Mr. Darcy.

l know this to be
a scandalous falsehood...

though not wishing
to injure him
by supposing it possible...

l instantly set off to make
my sentiments known.

lf you believed it
to be impossible...

l wonder you took the trouble
of coming so far.

To hear it contradicted,
Miss Bennet.

Your coming will be rather
a confirmation, surely...

if indeed such
a report exists.
If?

Do you then pretend
to be ignorant of it?

Has it not been industriously
circulated by yourself?
l have never heard of it.

And can you declare
there is no foundation for it?

l do not pretend
to possess equal frankness
with Your Ladyship.

You may ask a question
which l may choose
not to answer.
This is not to be borne.

Has my nephew made you
an offer of marriage?

Your Ladyship has declared it
to be impossible.
Let me be understood.

Mr. Darcy is engaged
to my daughter.

Now, what have you to say?
Only this.
If that is the case...

you can have no reason
to suppose he would
make an offer to me.
You selfish girl!

This union has been planned
since their infancy.

Do you think it can be
prevented by a young woman
of inferior birth...

whose own sister's
elopement...

resulted in a scandalously
patched-up marriage...

only achieved
at the expense of your uncle?

Heaven and Earth,
are the shades of Pemberley
to be thus polluted?

J
Now tell me once and for all
are you engaged to him?
l am not.

And will you promise
never to enter into
such an engagement?

l will not,
and l certainly never shall.

You have insulted me
in every possible way...

and can now have
nothing further to say.

l must ask you
to leave immediately.

(Elizabeth)
Good night.
[dog barking]

Lizzie, what on earth
is going on?

lt's iust a small
misunderstanding.
Lizzie.

Oh, for once in your life,
Ieave me alone!
[hens clucking]

title: Pride & Prejudice (9/10) Movie CLIP - Lady Catherine's Interrogation (2005) HD

comments.text: awful, watch the tv series much better lady Catherine performance...﻿
comments.author: Kevin Wright

comments.text:
I remember when I was really young and she said her nephew is suppose to 
marry ur daughter, ugh. I understand now that was way back and it was 
normal then.﻿
comments.author: Alexandria Bella

comments.text:
I adore Dame Judi when she plays strong authoritarian types - this, as 
Elizabeth I in Shakespeare in Love, M in the James Bonds, and the no 
nonsense yet libertine grandmum in Chocolat. Unfortunately when she is 
paired up with an actress of her age and stature she always plays the 
younger, more emotional, and "weaker" half. Notice this in Tea with 
Mussolini, Ladies in Lavender, and the Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (1 and 2) 
when she is paired with Dame Maggie Smith as well as in Cranford when she 
is with Dame Eileen Atkins. In both cases, Smith and Atkins play the elder 
half who is more cognitive, assertive and is clearly the "leader" of the 
pair.﻿
comments.author: miolim

comments.text: Dame Judi Dench, easily the greateast actress currently on the planet.﻿

comments.text:
+JWPhoto Relax :) It so amazing that you are so passionate about the book, 
as you should. Jane Austen's work is stunning, but you should give some 
credit to the people behind the movie adaptation, the whole crew and actors 
did a fine job. It musn't been easy and its a good movie. It could've been 
better, of course but its not a bad film
comments.author: the girl with no videos

comments.text:
+tatty lissette This stunning scene takes place in the "little wilderness" 
out in the back of Longbourn. Elizabeth Bennet's verbal duel with Lady 
Catherine de Bourgh is one of the great scenes in all literature. The book 
is about the landed gentry of the British Regency period. It's not 
Wuthering Heights. And most importantly, it 's not a silly romantic novel 
as this movie portrays it. I urge to to simply read the book to get a sense 
as to why it is such a highly regarded piece of english literature.
comments.author: JWPhoto
